text:
Hi Neal! I’m getting on just fine, I’m currently learning Nuke, getting to know the basics of paint and roto, nodes and shortcuts - using Steve Wright’s book and tutorials as you suggested. In a few weeks I will start at The Mill. Very very excited! 
How about you? Are you working on any projects at the moment

nice. you've prob heard this before but a couple of tips on roto. make sure you split up shapes, for example if you're rotoing a hand, split up the fingers as a roto shape each and even multiple parts of fingers like nail etc.
it take longer but you will get much better smoother results

also try to use minimum key frames as possible. you don't want to be rotoing on every frame as you roto will just boil. try every 10 frames and let nuke work out the middle bit. then go to every 5 frames and adjust where it's slipping and then every 2-3 frames if it's still slipping
I'm still leading and supervising on Happy Season 2 although should be all done end of March

Great advice! I usually split up shapes when working in After Effects, I will definitely use that same workflow in Nuke too. As for using minimum keyframes to avoid slipping, I never thought about that, very useful! 
Glad to hear! How do you find the role of leading and supervising? Do you get to work on set?

leading is busy. we've ramped up recently so i'm leadng about 16 artists at the mo. it basically just means i need to do any set up scripts that people can work from, check everyone has what they needs, answer questions if they're struggling to achieve something. QC their work to make sure it's technically correct before it goes to the client. The supervising part is checking everything in the screening room with the artists and spotting anything they can improve on before it goes to the client. things like is the focus on their elements matching the plate, is they key  working, is the lighting correct. It's not a typical supervisor rile on this show. normally you'd have a lead and a supervisor as separate roles but just combining for this show. Usually a supervisor would go on set too, but not in this case.

Sounds very busy! As full on as it sounds by having two roles on a project, It must be a great role though since you can help artists with your expertise! That’s one of the things I will have to get used to, I can ask for a a quick hand if I am struggling with something as I start. Being self taught and working on my own I’m used to figuring problems out by using brute force or sitting on it. Can’t wait to see how Season 2 comes together!
Yes, I was the same, trying figuring it out by googling, forums etc..but there's no quicker way than just asking someone. Make sure you constantly keep asking questions. BEST way to learn.
At the Mill there will be an ocean of knowledge, swim in it!
I like that metaphor ahah! Will definitely be asking a  lot of questions, not just when I’m struggling but even for tips. I am extremely lucky for this opportunity
